messages: e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (05:41): Hixie, AryehGregor is there a tentative date, or general timeframe, when the HTML5 spec is supposed to mature to the next phase?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:41): e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d: what do you mean by next phase?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:41): do you mean as far as W3C process, or something else?
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (05:42): currently in working draft, I assume the next is candidate recommendation
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:43): yeah, that's the next big step
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:43): but prior to that there's another step
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:43): which is so-called Last Call
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:43): which is actually more like First Call
ced6bfe1f650f6b338594d37eb7850d2 (05:43): How long is the Last Call?
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (05:44): Is there a tentative eta for that mike?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:44): we have not decided how long the LC for it will be
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:45): e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d: schedule from the chairs is here:
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:45): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Sep/0074.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:45): the date we are aiming to start LC is May 22
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:46): "LC resolution carries" = resolution from the group to agree to start LC
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:46): and what LC at W3C means is that the group must record every comment it receives about the spec during the LC period
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:47): and at the end of the LC period, publish a report listing the "disposition" for every comment
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:48): including whether whether any change was made to the spec based on the comment
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:50): what the HTML WG is doing right now is, the chairs are reviewing all escalated issues that have come in so far
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:50): where "escalated issues" means, cases where somebody in the group asked for a change to the spec but the change was rejected
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:51): those are cases that have to be adjudicated by the chairs
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:51): based on their review of all the available information about the issue
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:52): and the plan is to try to get all those open issues decided by the chairs, on behalf of the group, by April 22
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:52): ced6bfe1f650f6b338594d37eb7850d2: is some groups, the LC period is just 1 month or so
ced6bfe1f650f6b338594d37eb7850d2 (05:52): Ah cool
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:52): in this case, it will be significantly longer, though
ced6bfe1f650f6b338594d37eb7850d2 (05:53): reading the mailing list
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (05:53): plus theoritically we never exit a phase, but always enter a new phase. Aka we enter in a phase when all the requirements for entering are met
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (05:53): but that is just semantics
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:54): yeah, the phases all just accumulate
ced6bfe1f650f6b338594d37eb7850d2 (05:54): I am surprised I never joined w3 working group :x Doing that now.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:54): like karmic dust
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:57): anyway, Hixie originally estimated we would go to CR in 2012
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:57): and a lot of people scoffed at that as being too far in the future
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:57): when he said it back in 2006 or early 2007 or so
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (05:58): From prior experience and looking at the development thus far, I'd say that Feb/Mar 2010 sounds about right
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (05:58): (and given the type of specification that people were used to produce aka not a microscopically detailed specification ;) )
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (05:58): different expectations
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:59): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:59): anyway, all the above said, none of these dates really have any effect on end users of the actual technologies
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (05:59): or on most adopters of the technologies
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:00): I mean on content providers or developers
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:00): what really matters is what has actually been implemented
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:00): and how interoperably it's been implemented
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:00): and how stable it is
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:00): an example is WebSocket
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (06:01): I'm just happy MS is developing IE9 to be compliant with the new spec so developers wont have to waste another decade bickering over the inequities
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:02): yeah, they have done some great stuff so far, as far as getting important features implemented in IE9
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:02): but they have a lot left to do
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:02): everybody does
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:02): an good example is HTML5 forms support
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:02): we still have a long way to go on that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:03): as far as getting it implemented
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:03): and the example of WebSocket is one where we do already have some solid implementations
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:04): but the spec is not completely stable
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:04): for the protocol part
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (06:04): I'm intrigued to see what roll web-sockets and <canvas> once decently implemented
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:04): and implementations are all going to need to change still
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:05): canvas is probably the most stable new feature from HTML5 that's actually been implemented
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (06:05): I'm not really sold on regular expressions defined in dev source though
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:05): in what context?
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (06:06): for instance input type=email pattern="RegEx"
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (06:09): although, i guess that's more of an implementation bit, as it does have valid use for non-security type instances, such as a name or date
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:10): yeah, but I supposed naive developers are certainly going to find ways to do stupid things with it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:10): but that's true of exposing any kind of feature like that to the masses
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (06:10): svg is more exciting than canvas IMO. once IE supports it, adoption is going to take off
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (06:11): 3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653: it's not an either-or at all
